8.1.4 Perecibilidade dos alimentos

Alimentos são produtos perecíveis (em bo a parte) e, por esse motivo, sua comercialização demanda alguns cuidados para que se possa garantir a qualidade. Para o caso das plataformas estudadas , no presente estudo de caso, essa preocupação aumenta . A venda de alimentos próximos d a data de venciment o agrava a percepção dos usuários em relação à segurança dos produtos, e de acordo com as entrevistas, a perecibilidade dos alimentos foi identificada como uma especificidade relevante no caso das PDAs . Segundo a entrevistada E, “o grande desafio do alimen to é que ele deve ser recolhido e consumido rápido. Porque geralmente são alimentos que estão um pouquinho mais maduros” . Essas startups comercializam produtos com prazo de validade próximo ao vencimento e, com isso, esses alimentos estão no limite do que é considerado próprio ao consumo humano . Essa condição tem como consequência um esforço adicional no planejamento das transações comerciais.

Para a plataforma C, por exemplo, que comercializa grandes cargas de produtos que estão próximo s ao vencimento, a entrevistada afirma a importância de conectar essa carga a parceiros que possam absorver todo esse alimento, sem que se transfira o desperdício de um ator para outro. Toda essa logística e estruturação dessa transação comercial é agravada por conta da pere cibilidade dos alimentos. Essa variável precisa ser considerada em todas as transações realizadas e agrava algumas das barreiras encontradas.
8.2 Soluções propostas

Os entrevistados apontaram algumas medidas adotadas nesse sentido, com intuito de solucionar as barreiras encontradas. Dentre elas, a garantia do preço e da qualidade dos produtos comercializados, a necessidade de estabelecer um canal de comunicação com clientes e

parceiros comerciais e o es tabelecimento de parcerias com estabelecimentos comerciais renomados , por exemplo . O Quadro 20 apresenta as soluções propostas para solução dessas barreiras considerando as suas especificidades .

As soluções mencionadas no Quadro 20 foram alternativas encontradas pelos fundadores das plataformas para superar as barreiras que surgiram no desenvolvimento e estruturação de seus negócios. Essas soluções foram mencionadas no decorrer das entrevistas e serão discuti das a seguir.
8.2.1 Soluções propostas para superação das barreiras culturais

Estabelecer um canal de comunicação com os consumidores e com os parceiros comerciais foi uma estratégia sugerida pelos entrevistados , para responder possíveis dúvidas sobre a utilização das plataformas. A intenção é aproximar as plataformas dos usuários e dos estabelecimentos parceiros com intuito de solucionar a resistência encontrada. Para o entrevistado D, “o desenvolvimento de canais de comunicação é a maneira que pode tornar uma empresa exponencial. Tanto um canal de comunicação com o usuário ensinando (a utilizar a plataformas), como um canal de comunicação de um passo a passo pro parceiro (atores do food service)”. Esses canais de comunicação esclareceriam dúvidas e aproximariam os consumidores e parceiros com a plataforma. Os entrevistados acreditam que as barreiras culturais podem ser superadas através de estratégias de comunicação eficientes que possam encorajar e informar consumidores e atores do sistema alimentar e , consequentemente, incentivá -los na adesão às iniciativas que visam o combate à PDA no Brasil.

No intuito de superar a resistência de usuários, o s entrevistados A e D mencionaram a necess idade da fiscalização e do monitoramento dos estabelecimentos parceiros das plataformas (para garantia da qualidade) . Os fundadores comentaram sobre a necessidade da presença física nos estabelecimentos para visitas e esclarecimentos. A fundadora da Plataf orma E aposta na criação de “ um time que visita, levanta e tem uma busca ativa por ONGs e doadores”. Esses parceiros são avaliados criteriosamente para que eles tenham “um portfólio de ONGs validadas dentro do sistema”. Segundo os entrevistados, a fiscaliz ação é essencial para garantir que os parceiros comerciais cumpram com os padrões exigidos (quantidade e qualidade dos produtos excedentes comercializados ).

Além disso, a associação a estabelecimentos conhecidos e com boa reputação, foi mencionada como est ratégia para superação da resistência dos consumidores (“eu tenho que garantir um bom parceiro, uma boa rede, alguém com nome”) . Segundo os entrevistados, a associação a estabelecimentos reconhecidos aumenta a confiança dos consumidores e atrai usuários para as plataformas . De acordo com o fundador da plataforma D, essa estratégia é uma das mais assertivas na prospecção de novos clientes, pois a plataforma ainda não é conhecida, então, o cliente é atraído pela boa reputação do parceiro comercial.

Segundo a literatura, é fundamental compreender as reais expectativas dos consumidores ( MAZZUCHELLI et.al, 2021) . Para superar a resistência dos usuários na adesão às plataformas, o entrevistado D sugere que, “o preço, a quantidade e a causa” são os principais atrativos para os usuários das plataformas , sendo o preço o mais importante . Assim como afirm aram Morone et.al (2018), o s entrevistados também concordam que os benefícios financeiros costumam ser atrativos tanto para consumidores quanto para os parceiros comerciais. Os parceiros comerciais são motivados pelo “aumento nas vendas e melhora na imagem da empresa ” (plataforma D) e os consumidores por “comprar alimentos de qualidade a preços reduzidos ” (plataforma A e D), por exemplo. Os entrevistados também acreditam que a promoção de benefícios sociais associados a seus negócios pode promover a imagem da empresa e contribuir com a adesão de consumidor es à causa. Para o entrevistado E, “existe uma geração de valor, social, ambiental e econômica, que justifica o pagamento do serviço”. O entrevistado A também acredita que a apresentação de métricas referentes aos benefícios associados pode atrair parceiros comerciais e consumidores. A Plataforma A se associou a uma ONG que fornece esses dados para eles. Eles convertem o valor doado em refeições geradas, e o entrevistado acredita que esses número s têm impactos positivos na prospecção de parceiros comerciais e usuários. A entrevistada E também avalia positivamente
essa estratégia. Para ela, a geração de sses dados é importante para “ ajudar o doador a enxergar melhor essa ineficiência e isso é um valor agregado é importante.”
8.2.2 Soluções propostas para superação das barreiras financeiras

Para as dificuldades financeiras, alguns entrevistados declararam a importância de se obter o apoio de investidores e incubadoras na superação desses obstáculos. Por exemplo, o fundador da plataf orma D mencion ou a presença de um investidor anjo entre os 3 sócios do negócio e mencionou que também foi “acelerado por um parque tecnológico”. Mais recentemente, os fundadores da plataforma D participaram de um game show (Shark Tank Brasil), onde apresen taram seu projeto para investidores e conseguiram um investimento de R$ 450.000. Já a plataforma B participou de um programa de aceleração de startups e teve o aux ílio de uma multinacional do ramo de bebidas para finalização do desenvolvimento da plataform a. Quanto aos custos elevados, indicados como uma dificuldade relevante para todas as plataformas, os entrevistados demonstraram cautela nos investimentos , na expansão de seus negócios e na estruturação de seus modelos de negócios , como estratégia para superar essas restrições financeiras . Por exemplo, nota -se um crescimento lento e a não internalização da logística em seus modelos . Os entrevistados não realizam as entregas dos alimentos, que fica a cargo dos elos conectados por essas plataformas. Tais d ecisões podem ser vistas como alternativas à redução de custos das startups.
8.2.3 Soluções propostas para superação das barreiras organizacionais

Todo o processo de estruturação das startups enfrentou dificuldades diversas (falta de recursos financeiros , falta de know how tecnológico e de mercado , entre outras). Para superação dessas dificuldades e finalização dos projetos, as plataformas contaram com o apoio de incubadoras que possibilitaram a conclusão de etapas importantes, fornecendo conhecimento e recursos financeiros. Segundo a fundadora da plataforma B, “a plataforma ainda não estava 100% pronta, até que uma empresa do ramo de bebidas ajud ou a terminar e lançar (a plataforma) em outubro de 2018”. Outros entrevistados também mencionaram que particip aram de programas de ajuda ao desenvolvimento de startups para concluir seus projetos. Uma barreira organizacional relevante, mencionada no capítulo 7, é a estruturação da logística. Pensando nisso, a formação de redes foi apontada nas entrevistas como sol ução para

esse desafio. De acordo com a entrevistada E, a cooperação com ONGs favorece a organização da logística e transporte das doações (“A gente trabalha inclusive em parceria com as ONGs, porque elas têm infraestrutura logística. Então, quando tem uma grande doação de um supermercado, que uma ONG não consegue buscar, a gente aciona um banco de alimentos, aciona parceiros.”). Para o caso da plataforma C, a entrevistada sugere que a formação de cooperativas favoreceria e facilitaria a absorção de grande s quantidades de alimentos , pois, “a indústria tem volumes muito grandes, então, restaurantes e bares não conseguem absorver uma carreta inteira de um determinado produto”.

Outro ponto que dificulta a estruturação e organização das plataformas é a ausência de um benchmarking, por se tratar de um modelo de negócio novo para o mercado brasileiro . De acordo com o entrevistado A, “falta muita pesquisa no Brasil e eles se apropriam de dados internacionais” como base para o desenvolvimento de seus negócios, “mas, não necessariamente, esses dados retratam a nossa realidade”. Portanto, percebe -se mais uma vez, a relevância de estudos focados no caso brasileiro, para superação de barreiras diversas , fato que reafirma a relevância do presente estudo.
8.2.4 Soluções propostas para superação das barreiras regulatórias

Os autores são unânimes na afirmação de que é essencial a criação de políticas públicas específicas para o caso dos alimentos. No entanto, optou -se por não mencionar essa afirmação no quadro, pois essa s ugestão não depende do interesse dos entrevistados e está fora do poder de ação deles.
8.2.5 Soluções propostas para superação das barreiras tecnológicas

Os entrevistados afirmam que o desenvolvimento de plataformas digitais é um processo complexo, caro (“Foram nove meses de desenvolvimento do aplicativo. É um processo demorado. É um processo caro” – Entrevistado D) e requer conhecimentos que muitos deles não possuem (“A gente tem outro ponto não tão positivo, ninguém é da tecnologia ” – Entrevistado D). Para superar essas dificuldades, os entrevistados optaram por terceirizar o desenvolvimento da tecnologia. O fundador da plataforma digital A disse: “Nós não tínhamos a mínima ideia de como programa um aplicativo. Então a gente terceirizou” .

Essa dificuldade se agrava por se tratar de um negócio inovador. Segundo o entrevistado D, se tem “uma ideia do que é a plataforma lá fora. Mas, foi necessário desenhar d o zero a plataforma aqui” . Consequentemente, é necessário entender os anseios do mercado consumidor em paralelo ao desenvolvimento dos aplicativos. Para a entrevistad a E, “Qualquer aplicativo que hoje está na nossa vida, foi criado um ecossistema para que ele fosse utilizado” . Portanto, “não adianta só criar um aplicativo e lançar, é preciso lançar um novo modelo cultural de consumir e comprar alimento”.

Os entrevistados também menciona ram a necessidade de “promover acessibilidade” (Entrevistado A), “ usabi lidade e conteúdos atrativos para conseguir reter os usuários ” (Entrevistada B). Portanto, principalmente para interações B2C (business to consumer), os aplicativos devem ser funcionais, fáceis para navegar e rápidos. Principalmente porque ainda existe muita resistência dos usuários (barreiras culturais ) no contexto brasileiro . Outra proposta foi o estabelecimento de canais de comunicação com os parceiros comerciais e usuários dos aplicativos. Essa sugestão se aplica às plataformas que ligam o food service aos consumidores através da comercialização de excedentes. Para o fundador da plataforma D, “essa é a maneira de se tornar uma empresa exponencial” . A ideia é aproximar a plataforma dos atores envolvidos nas relações comerciais . Para os usuários, um esforço para ensiná -los a utilizar os aplicativos e esclarecendo possíveis dúvidas. Pa ra os parceiros comerciais, um passo a passo de como devem ser comercializados os alimentos, estabelecendo os padrões exigidos.
9 CONCLUSÕES

As plataformas digitais de combate à PDA são um fenômeno recente no Brasil . Ainda existem poucos dados sobre as alternativas no combate à perda e ao desperdício de alimentos no país , o que justifica a realização de estudos com o esse, que buscam compreender os desafios que os inovadores enfrentam e as estratégias que eles adotam para minimiz ar ess es ob stáculos . Segundo os entrevistados , “qualquer aplicativo que hoje está na nossa vida, foi criado um ecossistema para que ele fosse utilizado” (Uber e iFood, por exemplo), “não adianta só criar um aplicativo e lançar, você tem que lançar um novo modelo cult ural de consumir e comprar alimento” , e para criar um ambiente favorável, é necessário compreender os desafios e desenhar soluções para eles.

O presente estudo encontrou barreiras culturais, financeiras, organizacionais, regulatórias e tecnológicas . As ba rreiras identificadas nas entrevistas ultrapassam a perspectiva tecnológica, portanto, essas plataformas não podem ser vistas apenas como meros marketplaces digitais, mas, sobretudo, como “agentes de conexão” no sistema alimentar que visam à recuperação de alimentos não comerciais. Essas plataformas conectam atores diversos e estruturam todas as transações comerciais realizadas . Assim, a tecnologia desempenha um papel importante, mas outros fatores também constituem barreiras críticas para a implementação d essas soluções.

Por exemplo, e xistem fortes aspectos culturais que levam ao baixo engajamento dos atores envolvidos nessas relações comerciais. Para os entrevistados, a maioria dos atores do sistema alimentar não enxergam as estratégias de combate à PDA como uma oportunidade econômica , pois considera m o desperdício como parte de seus modelos de negócios , incluindo o custo desse desperdício no preço dos seus produtos. Esse é um cenário cômodo para esses atores e enquanto não houver um amparo legal (com a criação de leis eficientes no combate à PDA) , essa dificuldade será difícil de transpor.

No cenário brasileiro, as plataformas digitais ainda surgem na ausência de uma política nacional para redução da perda e do desperdício de alimentos e a maioria das di ficuldades mencionadas nas entrevistas , são consequência ou são agravadas , pela ausência de um ambiente institucional que favoreça o desenvolvimento dessas iniciativas, e assim, os modelos são desenvolvidos considerando essas dificuldades, o que onera aind a mais esse processo. Nesse contexto , a necessidade da criação de um ambiente institucional favorável, com a criação de leis eficientes, foi reforçada por todas as entrevistas, pois, enquanto descartar for mais barato

que comercializar ou doar um excedente as empresas vão continuar optando pelo descarte. Outro ponto relevante e discutido ao longo do trabalho se refere à interdependência entre as barreiras citadas. Há uma forte relação causal entre as barreiras, o que impossibilita que sejam compreendidas de forma isolada.

Com o intuito de superar essas barreiras, os entrevistados sugeriram algumas medidas. Dentre as propostas estão: a associação a parceiros comerciais com boa reputação e a promoção de atrativos financeiros , vistas como as medidas mais assertivas na prospecção de usuários. Já para a solução dos problemas de logística, os entrevistados sugeriram a formação de cooperativas como uma alternativa viável para a solução desses problemas. Outra proposta foi a formaçã o de um canal de comunicação com os clientes e parceiros comerciais , para aproximar solucionar possíveis dúvidas . Além disso, os entrevistados aposta ram na elaboração de métricas (para demonstrar os benefícios provenientes das estratégias de recuperação de alimentos ) e na fiscalização de seus parceiros como forma de superar as dificuldades encontradas. Todos os entrevistados também mencionaram a importância da criação de leis específicas para o caso da PDA, ressaltando, mais uma vez, que m uitas das barreira s não existir iam se houvesse um ambiente institucional favorável .

Os resultados deste estudo apontam informações relevantes para o caso brasileiro e chama m a atenção para a importância de políticas públicas e instrumentos específicos como incentivos fiscai s e legislação específica, para estimular o surgimento de diferentes tipos de iniciativas e soluções no combate à PDA no Brasil. No entanto, os dados aqui apresentados não podem ser generalizados devido ao número restrito de plataformas estudadas . Esse bai xo número de empresas entrevistadas está condicionado aos poucos casos existentes no país, no início de 2020 (que já são maiores em 2022) .

Vale ressaltar que t odas as plataformas foram entrevistadas no início de suas operações. Portanto, é possível que nov as barreiras tenham surgido com o tempo. Por exemplo, nesse período as cinco plataformas sofreram com a pandemia da COVID -19, que afetou principalmente as plataformas A e D, que possuem interações B2C ( business to consumer ). Em um contato mais recente com o fundador da plataforma A, o mesmo mencionou que ampliou suas operações para comercialização de copos e canudos reutilizáveis e outros utensílios produzidos a partir de material reciclado, como alternativa ao período dos restaurantes fechados. No entanto, as cinco plataformas analisadas seguem em operação, enfrentando seus desafios e expandindo seus negócios .

Por fim, recomenda -se uma exploração da perspectiva dos consumidores brasileiros (possíveis barreiras, motivações e expectativas) sobre a adoção de p lataformas de redução do desperdício de alimentos. Afinal, o presente estudo está focado na percepção do lado da oferta (perspectiva dos proprietários e desenvolvedores de plataformas digitais), não considerando as expectativas do lado da demanda (na persp ectiva do consumidor).

PLATAFORMA A

Pergunta: “O que é a “Plataforma A”? Como ela surgiu? ” (Nos apresentamos, explicamos os objetivos do nosso trabalho e pedimos que o entrevistado contasse como a ideia surgiu, quais eram as suas motivações e quais foram os primeiros desafios encontrados. )

Entrevistado : “Numa passagem de domingo pra segunda eu n ão tava conseguindo dormir e então liguei a TV e estava passando uma reportagem sobre startups que fizeram negócios de impacto . Uma dessas empresas era de Hong Kong e se chamava food save . Eram rapazes que se juntaram para vender exc edente de padaria . Eu achei aquilo sensacional. No dia seguinte encontrei meu atual sócio (na época colega de trabalho) e perguntei como acontecia nos restaurantes da família dele (questionando sobre como era tratado o desperdício n esses restaurantes), e ele ligou pra mãe dele para perguntar . Ela respondeu que sobrava muita comida. Foi quando eu sugeri para ele que isso era algo legal da gente estudar. Já fazia alguns anos que eu buscava algo para trabalhar em paralelo ao que eu trabalhava (o entrevistado era engenheiro civil de uma grande construtora). E decidimos olhar no fim de semana. Foi quando fizemos nosso primeiro modelo de teste. O nosso MDP (método do diagrama de precedência) . Fomos no domingo. Esperamos todos os funcionários comerem já no final do expediente. Todos os funcionários almoçaram. Daí pedimos para que ninguém retirasse o que tinha sobrado nas gondolas , e tiramos fotos do que tinha nas gondolas. Tinha muita comida. Montamos 14 marmitas com essa comida para levarmos para jantar nas noss as casas e ainda assim sobrou comida. Naquele dia levamos 7 marmitas para cada casa e alimentamos 20 pessoas naquela noite com o excedente de 1 estabelecimento daqui de Londrina e ainda jogamos comida for a. Apesar de sermos da área, minha esposa tem restau rante e a família dele inteira, nunca tínhamos olhado para essa situação. E nós como bons engenheiros, olhamos aquilo e vimos uma grande oportunidade de negócio. Então, o surgimento da ideia da empresa foi aí. Foi desse teste. Primeiramente, a gente queria trabalhar nesses tipos de restaurantes, que eram buffet, porque a gente sabia que o excedente era muito forte . A gente ia coletar e vender de alguma forma , posteriormente. Essa era a primeira ideia do projeto. Daí fomos amadurecendo o modelo de negócio e determinamos que íamos trabalhar juntos, começamos a estruturar, fizemos o CANVAS e o modelo de negócio da empresa . Depois de mais ou menos dois meses de bastante trabalho, nos perguntamos se ninguém já estava fazendo algo do tipo no mundo.

Até então , tudo que tínhamos achado, principalmente no Brasil, eram empresas que trabalhavam no atacado, no varejo, empresas que trabalhavam com grandes indústrias e comercializavam lotes de produtos que estavam prestes a vencer. Já tinham empresas atuando nesse sentido aqui no Brasil. Mas, com alimentos na ponta e muito perecíveis, não tinha nada. Daí fomos pesquisar. Nessa época já tínhamos a ideia muito mais consolidada e quando a gente digitou exatamente o que a gente tinha escrito para definir o que nós éramos: uma empresa de base tecnológica que ia vender excedente dos estabelecimentos a preços reduzidos, comida de qualidade a preço reduzido. Basicamente é isso que a gente faz. Quando digitamos isso no Google, a primeira que apareceu foi uma empresa do Reino Unido ch amada Too Good to Go. Quando descobrimos que essa empresa existia, parecia que a gente tinha feito o site deles. O que estava escrito lá era exatamente a mesma coisa que tínhamos escrito aqui. E a gente não tinha conhecimento da existência dessa empresa. Num primeiro momento tivemos um baque, porque achávamos que nossa ideia era exclusiva e única. Só que logo na sequência pensamos, se já existe uma empresa lá que ta fazendo e ta dando certo, então tem uma grande oportunidade de dar certo aqui . Obviamente q ue existem grandes barreiras no Brasil diferentes da Europa. Essa empresa esta atuando num mercado totalmente diferente do nosso. Mas, a gente acreditava que existia , ainda assim, um potencial. Pesquisamos isso em setembro de 2018, mais ou menos e essa emp resa já estava trabalhando em seis países. Tá certo que na Europa, cada país é um estado do Brasil, praticamente. Mesmo assim, ela estava atuando em países diferentes, cresceu bastante, estava com bastante usuário e a gente achou que teria uma grande oport unidade aqui no Brasil também . Eles acabaram ajudando bastante a gente a finalizar a construção do projeto, porque a gente tinha muita dúvida ainda sobre como íamos fazer. Se teria entrega ou não , por exemplo. Abstract Food waste is a concern in high and low -income countries, reinforcing the importance of developing different strategies to address the pro blem. Among the various solutions to tackle food waste are digital platforms. Food waste -reducing platforms (FWRP) have proliferated in different countries; however, most existing studies refer to them in high -income countries. These platforms are a recent phenomenon in Brazil, which somehow explains why little is known about the barriers and challenges faced by entrepreneurs. In this context, this study aims to identify and explore the main barriers and challenges faced by Brazilian innovators of food waste reducing platforms and the strategies to minimize them. Our methodology is based on exploring case examples of Brazilian FWRP . We applied semi -structured interviews with the digital platform's founders and adopted the content analysis method. As a result , we identified multiple barriers and challenges. Technology plays an important role, but other factors constitute critical barriers to implementing these solutions in Brazil . Some examples were: the lack of knowledge of consumers concerning food -sharing p latforms; the resistance of commercial partners to realize that there is an economic opportunity to combat food waste; the lack of food waste measurement and indicators; most food system actors consider food waste as part of current business models, among others. The innovators realized they must adapt their

business models to couple economic, social, and environmental benefits and promote strategies to reduce the entry barriers. For them, there is a strong relationship between reducing waste and helping to minimize food insecurity.
KEYWORDS: food waste reduction , digital platforms, circular economy, food sharing, business model
1 INTRODUCTION

Food waste is an environmental, social, and economic issue affecting high -income countries to middle and low -income countries (Gustavson et al. ; 2011). If food waste were considered a country, it would be among the world's largest emitters of greenhouse g ases (FAO, 2015). Paradoxically, while more than one -third of the total food produced globally is lost and wasted, hundreds of millions still live under severe food insecurity. FAO estimates that more than two billion people are exposed to some level of fo od insecurity ((FAO, IFAD, UNICEF, WFP and WHO, 2020). Before the COVID -19 pandemic, around 690 million people were undernourished (FAO, IFAD, UNICEF, WFP and WHO, 2021). Unfortunately, estimations indicate that the COVID -19 pandemic may have inserted more 132 million people into food insecurity . (FAO, IFAD, UNICEF, WFP and WHO, 2021) Reducing food loss and waste is widely seen as a strategy to improve food affordability and security and address environmental sustainability (FAO, 2019). Tackling food loss a nd waste collaborates to achieving some of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) established by the United Nations. Specifically, the SDG Target 12.3 calls for halving per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reducing food loss es along production and supply chains (including post -harvest losses) by 2030.

There are differences between food loss and food waste terminologies following FAO definition s. Food loss refers to decreasing food quantities or quality along the value chain stages from harvest up to, but not including, the retail level. Food waste means those food removed from the human food supply chain in the retail, foodservice , and household sectors (Gustavson et al, 2011, United Nations Environment Programme , 2021; Parfi tt et al., 2010). According to Food Waste Index Report 2021, around 931 million tonnes of food waste was generated in 2019, 61 percent of which was from households, 26 percent from foodservice , and 13 percent from retail. The report also points out that fo od waste per capita is similar among individuals
with similar income ranges (United Nations Environment Programme, 2021) , indicating that families and individuals from lower and higher -income c ountries may present high levels of food waste .

A diary study by Porpino et al., 2018 indicated that Brazilian families (household level) waste approximately 130 kilos per year, a similar value observed in high -income countries. Werderits Silva et al. (20 21) indicated that only 37,5% of retail companies surveyed have loss prevention departments to measure waste. These results reinforce the need for implementing several strategies to decrease food waste along with these sectors.

Tackling food waste require s many strategies (Principato et al., 2021; Garrone et al., 2014; Papargyropoulou et al., 2014; FAO, 2015; Morone et al., 2017). Among these solutions, digital food-sharing platforms have emerged as one of the most promising solutions to connect the differ ent parties along the food chain to reduce waste (Harvey et al., 2020; Mullick et al., 2020; Mazzuchelli et al., 2021; Ciuli et al., 2020). Food -waste reducing platforms (FWRP) have proliferated in different countries and regions, such as the United States , Europe, and Asia (Oroski, 2020). However, these platforms are a recent phenomenon, with many cases arising worldwide, mainly in the last five years .

According to Mazzuchelli et al. (2021), FWRP can encompass both applications and websites and are used t o interact with a wide range of actors, including volunteers, operational staff, companies, stakeholders, in addition to those on the supply (food providers) and demand (food recipients). For Michelini et al. (2018), digital platforms optimize existing res ources and are valuable instruments for redistributing unused or underutilized products and services within society. At first glance, FWRPs are low -cost alternatives in connecting actors (NGOs, supermarkets, restaurants, etc) who want to sell or donate sur plus and non -commercial food to other organizations or people (Cane and Parra, 2020). FWRPs can fulfill their role in society as long as they consider some important challenges such as distances covered, conflict of interests, perishability of traded food, among others (Oroski, 2020; Mullick et al., 2021). According to the existing literature, the implementation of circular initiatives, such as these diital platforms, must surpass a series of barriers that are not restricted to the technological dimension ( Ciuli et al.; 2020; Oroski, 2020; Vermunt et al., 2019; Kirchherr et al., 2018). These circularity barriers impose the development of circular business models that can foresee a set of obstacles such as economic, cultural, organizational, among others.

Some recent studies have explored different FWRP cases to identify how these platforms function , technology's role, and the main challenges for implementing these initiatives. Mazzuchelli et al (2021) explored the case of OLIO platform and draw attention to aspects such as the consumer's perception of the social and environmental responsibility of the platforms, in addition to other aspects such as familiarity with the application and the sense of community. MULLICK et al. (2020) and CANE e t al. (2020) argue that consumer s' behavior and engagement depend on consumer familiarity with technology to promote new ways of consuming food. Apostolidis et al (2021) argue that apps need to invest in building a relationship of trust so that cultural ba rriers such as social stigma regarding the purchase of food through food recovery apps can be overcome. Moltene et al, 2021 and Harvey et al, year also cite the building of a trust relationship between the platform and its potential users as a critical barrier to the growth of these devices. SARTI et al. (2017) explore how the absence of an institutional and legal environment can inhibit the growth of these platforms , given that consumers are still unaware of how these solutions work and feel insecure abou t the quality of the food. In their work, Ciuli et al (ano) argue that the role of platforms should go beyond connecting donors and recipients. Digital platforms must have other functions to promote circularity in the food system, such as informing, protec ting, mobilizing, integrating and measuring. The authors explored different real cases of platforms that indicate that these solutions need to advance in their functionality so that it is actually possible to introduce new forms of food production and cons umption.

However, as mentioned above, FWRPs are still a recent phenomenon in the Brazilian context, which little is known about the barriers and challenges entrepreneurs face in the country context . Studies based on cases examples from other countries (Di Leo et al., 2020; Cane and Parra, 2020) , mainly from high -income countries, may enrich the discussion about FWRP, though they do not afford specificities about a middle and low -income country such as Brazil . In 2020 the Law 14.016/2020 that allows the dona tion of non -commercialized food or meals as long as they are fit for human consumption was approved (Agencia Senado, 2020). However, most food system actors are not confident to donate surplus food. Despite an advance in legislation that intends to remove barriers to food donation (Werderits Silva et al., 2021) , we do not have an implemented national strategy to tackle food waste in a Brazilian context. In this context, we propose to respond to the following questions: What are the main barriers to implemen ting these technologies and circular solutions in the Brazilian context? Do the barriers to the circularity of surplus and non -commercial food go beyond technology? What are the

main challenges innovators face in a low - and middle -income country with no national strategy to combat food waste? This article aims to identify and explore the main barriers and challenges faced by Brazilian innovators of FWRP and the strategies adopted to minimize these barriers. Then, we propose exploring cases examples in the B razilian context to enlighten the discussion about FWRP in a developing country. Based on interviews with the founders of FWRP, we apply a content analysis method to investigate the main barriers and strategies to implementing these circular innovations.

This study presents contributions from theoretical and practical insights. This work indicates that barriers to implementing the FWRP surpass the technological perspective from a theoret ical perspective. Another theoretical contribution refers to the discu ssion of circularity within the food system. According to Garrone et al. (2014), specific challenges (e.g. perishability and food safety ) emerge when we promote circularity into the food system based on food waste recovery strategies. Therefore, exploring specific cases in the food system sheds light on aspects that would not be evidenced from cases studies from other production systems.

Moreover, this study adds differentiated platforms that combat waste to the scarce literature on the subject. Despite the emergence of several cases of FWRP in the recent period, there are still few studies on the subject, even more so in low - and middle -income countries. This study also brings practical implications with valuable insights to innovators and policymakers in developing countries like Brazil. These practical implications mainly refer to understanding the main barriers along the implementation process of platforms and possible strategies to be addressed to minimize them.

This article is structured as follows. Section 2 outlines the method utilized. Section 3 presents the results obtained from the investigation based on interviews. Section 4 discusses the main findings compared with the extant literature. Finally, section 5 outlines the final considerations.
2 MATERIALS AND METHODS

This study explores case examples of FWRP, adopting the methodology of multiple case studies, which represent an interesting approach when the focus is on contemporary phenomena inserted in some real-life context and questions such as "how" and "why" are raised (Yin, 2003). Therefore, as a recent phenomenon in Brazil, FWRPs constitute a new research topic. Based on the case studies, we mapped the challenges faced by entrepreneurs in structuring their initiatives

and how they addressed solutions to overcome them. The research design is illustrated in Figure 1 and involves three main steps, namely case selection, data collection, data analysis, described as follows.
Figure 1 - Methodology steps
2.1 Cases selection

We identified the cases examples through searching in different sources: applications on google play, food waste specialists, and on the web search (Google, Linkedin, Facebook, among others). Since there are few examples of FWRP in Brazil, the number of cases selected is limited. We applied three case selection criteria: (1) platforms that focus on commercialization or donation of surplus food, non -commercial standard (imperfect) food and close to date expiration, or the provision of services as food donation/sharing. (2) for -profit platforms were named by Michellini et al. (2018) as sharing for profit , excluding non -profit plat forms examples. (3) platforms already in operation allow the survey to identify challenges for structuring business models. 2.2 Data collection
The cases were explored based on information obtained through semi -structured interviews with the founders of the platforms selected for the study. The researchers conducted the
interviews openly and flexibly to allow respondents to emphasize topics they c onsidered critical (Gioia et al., 2012).

Interviews happened between January and November 2020 and lasted between 90 and 120 min on average , and were carried out face -to-face via online platforms (Zoom or Google Meet). Before the interviews, we gathered p rimary (platform websites) and secondary data (online newspapers and magazines) about the platforms to draw an initial idea about their business models.
2.3 Data analysis

We adopted the content analysis approach to identify innovators' main barriers and challenges . The interviews were transcribed manually by two research team members to avoid missing relevant parts. Then, researchers compared, revised, and merged their versions into a single document (textual body) per respondent. Afterward, the transcri bed interviews (doc format) were inserted into the NVivo version 11, a qualitative and content analysis software. According to Mayring (2014) and Bardin (2011), content analysis is a technique for data analysis according to a systematic process of research and message description, whose objective is to condense ideas and build categories for further interpretation (BARDIN, 2011).

We opted for the inductive method, when researchers did not start from an a priori definition of the analysis categories, follow ing the procedures recommended by Bardin (2011) and Mayring (2014). An inductive analysis aims to identify categories directly from the material itself, not from theoretical considerations. Bengtsson (2016) states that in the inductive method, the research er analyzes the text with an open mind to identify significant issues by answering the research question. As it is a new subject in the literature, we considered the inductive method more appropriate to map the barriers faced by innovators and strategies a dopted to minimize them. Each researcher analyzed the interviews separately, initially doing a fluctuating reading and seeking a first perception of the messages contained in them. After, researchers proceeded with several readings to identify the barriers (categories) mentioned by the interviewees of each platform.

In order to ensure the data triangulation, avoiding the bias of the analysis due to the interpretation of a single researcher, both researchers analyzed individually and after discussed the res ults and reviewed the coding process performed in an iterative and collaborative process.

Finally, we also collected the strategies implemented by the entrepreneurs to deal with the challenges along the content analysis process. Throughout the interviews, we asked innovators about their business models to identify how they managed these barriers and which solutions they addressed. In this work, we follow Teece (2010) definition that understands the business model from three main dimensions: (1) value propo sition (what is offered as value and to whom), (2) value creation (how to generate value from own resources and partners), and (3) value capture (strategies for obtaining economic value).
3 RESULTS

Based on content analysis procedures described in the p revious section, we identified the main barriers and challenges entrepreneurs face along the development and insertion of FWRPs . These barriers are listed, depicted, and illustrated through excerpts from the interviews. Some statements have been edited for length and clarity. Beyond the barriers, we also identified the main strategies adopted by innovators to minimize them.

Barrier/Challenge #1: Stigma about food surpluses and leftovers Respondents were very concerned about the stigma about food surpluses and leftovers (a misconception that shared food is not good quality food). Some people believe traditional markets do not accept this food due to their supposed low quality or attractiveness. An important strategy adopted by platforms was to dissociate th eir businesses from this belief through partnering with high reputation actors. For this, platforms prospect commercial partners (food providers) with expressive brands in the cities where they operate. They agree that disconnecting food recovery from sell ing leftovers or poor quality food can decrease consumer's mistrust and resistance.

“We are a technology -based company that sells surplus food at reduced prices. Good quality food at reduced prices” “We seek to have the best restaurants in town on our platform” (Platform A) “We guarantee that the food is good. “ “But how do we get it? Through linking our brand to recognized foodservice actors “(Platform B)
Barrier/Challenge #2: Assuring food safety

Food safety is a big concern for food -sharing platfor ms, mainly due to food perishability conditions. Most food to be shared requires a short time to be commercialized. Interviewees affirmed that the protocols and processes regarding food safety are under the responsibility of food providers. Nevertheless, t hey require some safety proceedings to accept a new commercial partner as a member of the platform (e.g., signing contracts that guarantee the safety of the food to be marketed). Their entrance depends on verifying hygiene, handling, and preservation condi tions through previous in -field visits. An excerpt from interview B exemplifies the topic: "We make a filter; we authorize their entrance in the platform after visiting the establishment" "The issue of food itself is already delicate" "A food close to exp iring date is even more delicate" “The partner has to ensure food safety by contract” (Platform B)

Barrier/Challenge #3: Most food system actors do not perceive food waste -reducing strategies as an economic opportunity and consider food waste as part of t heir current business models According to interviewees, most food system actors do not perceive food waste -reducing strategies as an economic opportunity and consider food waste as part of their current businesses models. Food waste is not measured or qua ntified, blinding their leading causes. For Respondent C, surplus food is a “system failure” provoked by operational inefficiencies derived from the lack of knowledge about demand and supply and forecasting errors. Consequently, food waste is often “price d” in products sold by the food system actors. This scenario turns most difficult for potential commercial partners to perceive an economic advantage in giving rise to businesses to tackle waste, which explains the low engagement of these actors. Deep - rooted cultural aspects, organizational constraints, and eventual adjustments in operational processes mean higher investments and additional complexity. These arguments try to explain why food system actors consider “normal” to waste in Brazil.

“Many establi shments believe it is not viable to reduce food waste”; “ they [food service] consider food waste as part of their business models”. “Beyond, many [food service actors] have no idea of how much they waste” (Platform A) “Most of food service actors are sma ll and family businesses. Many can not afford strategies to measure food waste and insert it in their prices ” (Platform B) “food waste is a system failure” (Platform C)

“I realized that a huge amount of product in perfect consumption conditions is lost in the food industry, often missing 3 or 4 months to the expiration date. The industry incinerates or disposes of them. ” (Platform D) Despite the difficulties described above, the founder of FWRP admitted to embracing the economic discourse at first glance to prospect partners they believe are most susceptible to monetize surpluses food. The discourse bases on generating extra revenues through reducing wastes and recovering their costs. Interviewee B, for example, said that they relied on economic appeal as a way to engage commercial partners initially:

“ I want to give them [food service] a chance to create markets to surpluses, the food they have not commercialized. That food is not leftover; it is not garbage. It is good food.” “We want to monetize them [f ood service]. “Instead of distributing food surplus to employees or even sending it to the garbage, we propose a solution to recover their cost.” (Platform B)

Barrier/Challenge # 4: Lack of technological background to develop the platforms The technology appeared in interviewees' discourses as a “stepping stone” to operationalize FWRP. The development of digital platforms and applications is quite complex, costly, and requires specific knowledge that many entrepreneurs do not domain. Respond ents signaled that technology plays a crucial role in making their businesses viable, especially for digital platforms that sell food surpluses at discount prices (Platform A and B), based on B2C (business to consumer) interactions. Those apps must be func tional, easy to navigate (user -friendly), and quickly disseminate information from food providers to recipients, mainly because the latter presents high cultural barriers to this type of business in the Brazilian context. For interviewee D, technology enab les connecting different parties along the value chain, giving higher visibility to food with no commercial appeal into traditional markets. Respondents also highlighted how they struggled to meet the high costs of developing and adapting the platforms since they hired specialized technological firms.

"Here in Brazil, you must show consumers what the platform means and how it functions; we must convince people to try on and to trust in inserting their credit card data. We spent much energy to make people t rust in our app, in our brand” (Platform A)

“But nobody [on the team] is tech person. Developing a platform is very expensive, it is absurdly costly, especially when designing the code from zero” (Platform B) “Our business is technology, not merely buying and selling [food], the technology permits to access what [food] is available, who can purchase and how to connect the parties” (Platform D)

Barrier/Challenge #5: Coupling economic, environmental, and social goals in their business models A common challe nge signaled by all interviewees is providing beyond economic (generating extra revenues and/or reducing costs with the final disposal of waste goals) and environmental benefits (reducing food waste), including social benefits in their value propositions. Respondents underlined that their initiatives are, in essence, businesses that propose actual social impacts. They do not want to be seen as businesses merely from an economic perspective, but above all as businesses that offer real benefits to society. Th e following excerpts illustrate their positioning:

"When we started our project, we did not just want to talk about food waste, we realized that we should be a company that really contributes to society" "we wish to be a company with truly social impact" " that makes a difference where we are acting" (Platform A) "Our proposal, our mission, is against food waste, but we are different." if we circulate good food to different parties of the chain, we will not need, in 2050, to increase food production by 70%. Food waste is not just an environmental issue, where organic waste is one of the biggest causes of the greenhouse effect, or even just an economic problem, in which one -third of food is lost or wasted. It is essentially a huge social problem. In Brazil alo ne, we have millions of people suffering from hunger. (Platform B) “We generate social, environmental and economic value .....” (Platform C) In the face of this, respondents adapted their value propositions to reconcile multiple benefits (economic, environ mental, and social) toward minimizing possible tensions. For example, Platform A realized that its starting business model did not reach people under food insecurity, not delivering the intended social benefit. Below, an excerpt that exemplifies this issue :

“our project, by itself, does not help to minimize hunger directly. Even we increase food affordability through lower prices, they are people who can buy" we realized that something was missing out in our initial business model,” (Platform A ) The founde rs revised their original business model to comply with the social perspective. As a solution, they partnered with an NGO that distributes food to charities. For each transaction made on the platform, a cash donation is transferred to NGO that converts int o food to vulnerable people.

Barrier/Challenge #6: Ensuring fair, affordable, and attractive prices In order to make their businesses competitive compared to traditional markets, FWRP must ensure fair, affordable, and attractive prices. Prices need to be attractive enough to encourage consumers and commercial establishments to buy non -standard food. Even though vulnerable people are not the target of platforms A and B (surplus food resellers), they even see lower prices as a strategy to expand their propo sal to more differentiated social classes. The founder of platform D believes their business competes directly with waste disposing costs. “We try to convince our partner to set a price good for everyone” “for us, the consumer's perception is very relevan t; we intend to put at the first place the social cause.” (Platform A) “To adhere to the platform, our client [food service] must practice prices at least 50% off” (Platform B) “The industry and the distributor understand they need to get rid of it [food] at a more attractive price compared to the cost for final disposal” (Platform D)

Barrier/Challenge #7: Low engagement of Brazilian consumers to food waste cause (lack of knowledge about these platforms) The low engagement of consumers to food waste cause compromises the rising of food sharing platforms in Brazil based on responses of interviewees A and B. Entrepreneurs justify this perception based on Brazilian consumers' lack of awareness of food waste cause and lack of knowledge about these types of plat forms. For interviewee B, many Brazilian consumers do not know how to act in the face of the food waste issue. Innovators understand that a good
communication strategy could broaden consumers perception about food waste topic and make them more aware:

“The user is experimenting a new and more awareness manner of consumption”. “What you buy, what you eat matters.” “Our proposal is quite different from other consumption modes, where you buy and consume unconsciously. We know the first motivation to buy may be the price, but we show the consumer their role in reducing food waste” (Platform B) For Interviewee A when people embrace food waste cause they do not use food -sharing platforms just to buy food at lower prices. Moreover, they feel responsible for reduci ng food waste. To engage consumers, beyond the effort around communication strategies (as cited in barrier 1), the innovators credit to the technology an essential role through allowing interactions among the actors involved and providing more transparency . “Our strategy is to show consumers that they will not only buy cheaper food but also make part of a cause, “ Our advantage is giving opportunities to thousands of people to help reducing food waste. Every single person makes a difference, “what we propos e is that everyone can contribute and help to maximize the impact” (Platform A)

Barrier/Challenge #8: Low engagement of commercial partners to food waste cause Beyond the low engagement of consumers and customers related previously, platforms needed to wi thstand the low engagement of commercial partners (food providers). According to the interviews, food waste cause is not still perceived as a priority in the Brazilian landscape. Respondents affirmed that food providers, which involve actors from food ser vice (platforms A and B), retail (supermarkets in the case of platform C), and industry sector (platform D), are not committed to the food waste cause in general. For instance, interviewee C said that although retailers, more specifically larger supermarke t chains, have a department responsible for preventing losses, food recovery is not considered a primary activity for these actors. Retailers still believe that implementing preventive actions increases complexity and costs to their existing operational pr ocesses. The following excerpts indicate some of the difficulties faced by entrepreneurs in order to engage business partners:

“How could we propose a business when actors do not believe and perceive a demand exists? “in the beginning, it was very complica ted; potential clients ignored us ” “costs are hidden in selling prices” (Platform A) “My biggest problem today is putting the partner in the cause. Firstly, they enter motivated by sales increasing and reputation, not embracing the cause. We had to imple ment much effort to convince them to understand and embrace the food waste cause” (Platform B) “We are building a new market. To raise awareness on that side [commercial partners] , we spend a lot of energy and time “unfortunately, the issue of food waste is not on the agenda in our country. This topic is still out of public and private actors agenda” (Paltform C) “Retailers will not buy a product close to its expiration date and do not want to take the risk of expiring that material. So the industry ends up incinerating and disposing food that still fit for human consumption conditions” (Platform D)

Barrier/Challenge #9: Showing the customer the value of their proposal and that their service must be remunerated By interviewees, showing the client the valu e of their proposal and making them to recognize their service must be remunerated requires a great relational effort. This fact confirms that FWRP are more than mere digital marketplaces. Platform C, for instance, highlighted that retailers initially enco untered difficulties in associating the donation process as an additional cost, such as the payment to a third -party company to structure their donation process. Consequently, many retailers prefer to discard than donate food since donating is more expensi ve than disposal. For interviewee D, actors from the food industry face great difficulties with tight margins, limiting them to paying for services.

“We need to prove to food donors that they can match food waste recovery with disposal costs reduction and adding value to their brands. The generation of social, environmental, and economic value justifies paying for this service. “Our job requires a great effort to raise awareness” (Platform C) "Some industries are unable to reduce their prices due to very r estrictive sell pricing policies” (Platform D)

As cited before, the challenge of platform C relies on convincing commercial partners to recognize its value proposition (donation process management service) as a service to be remunerated. The structuring of the donation process through the implementation and improvement of internal processes and offering a monitoring service along the donation process from start to end, ensuring food safety, traceability are the main value proposition of Platform C:

“We pro vide a fully customized and professional service in order to bring greater control and accuracy, more reporting, greater visibility, and traceability to customers platform donation process; we audit the NGOs, carry out an analysis and ensure that the NGO works properly (how it receives and distribute this food). we monitor donations in all steps involved reducing risks.” (Platform C)

Barrier/Challenge # 10: Lack of an institutional environment to foster sustainable and circular business models to fight fo od waste Respondents believe the absence of a favorable institutional environment impairs the creation of sustainable and circular businesses to reduce food waste in Brazil. They agree that FWRP represent s a “novelty” for most Brazilian people, leading to cultural, financial, and organizational barriers for businesses and consumers to adhere. One of the interviewees (Platform C) believes that the topic is out of the current Brazilian government's agenda. This condition inhibits the creation of an innovation ecosystem and the flourishment of food -waste - reducing startups. For interviewee D, the lack of specif policy instruments as tax incentives for food recovery activities explains how it is challenging to develop these businesses in Brazil. "One of the most important problems we face is that when the industry losses food, it declares it as losses and has tax relief"; "Many times when trying to commercialize the product costs more than incineration" ; “often the cost of disposal is less than trying to sell th e product and spending to deliver it” (Platform D)
4 DISCUSSIONS
This section examines the main barriers encountered in our study in the light of the extant literature and discusses the leading strategies innovators address to overcome them (see Figure

2). The content analysis of interviews identified ten different barriers and challenges faced by Brazilian FWRP. The interviews indicated that the founders of FWRP address the lack of awareness about food waste and the lack of knowledge of Brazilian consum ers as a triggering point to many of the barriers identified. The interviewees believe that the low engagement regarding food waste could be surpassed through communication strategies that encourage consumers and other food system actors to embrace circular practices regarding food waste reduction . Innovators also believe that fostering social impacts and empowering consumers results in more awareness and engagement. This result is in line with the role of inform ing to be played by FWRP according to Ciuli et al (2020).

Based on the existent literature (e.g: Apostolidis et al., 2021; Mazzuchelli et al. , 2021; Schanes and Stagl, 2019), consumer expectations around food -sharing platforms still need to be better understood by innovators to enable value co -creation. Morone et al. (2018) affirmed that the most significant stimulus for consumers to embrace food waste -reducing practices is the economic driver (buying food at lower prices). On the other hand, Ciuli et al. (2020) and Mazzuchelli et al. (2021) believe the critical point is becoming environmental and social benefits more visible. Some studies also call attention to the discrepancy between the discourse guided by a positive attitude towards food -sharing practices and actual consumer behavior, marked by some level of resistance that inhibits their adoption (Mazzuchelli et al., 2021). sustainability dimensions (economic, environmental and social) to dispel the consumer´s perception that food waste reducing platforms are merely discount platforms. In line with this perspective, Apostolidis et al (2021) argue that c onsumers buy surplus food not only to access affordable food but, above all, as an opportunity to help reducing food waste from restaurants and food businesses, in general. Cane and Parra, (2020) also claim that these platforms must be committed to social value propositions. These businesses only make sense for people if they prioritize and fulfill social promise (Mattila et al., 2020) . The study of Shanes and Stagl (2019) with Austrian consumers revealed they get involved in food sharing practices not only guided by individual benefits but, above all, the sense of community and morality. In short, interviewees claimed the relevance of changing the consumers' role from mere spectators to protagonists in reducing food waste and food insecurity.

In our findings, creating an image that shared food is a “good quality food” emerged as pivotal for Brazilian food -sharing platforms. While consu mers show some insecurity about buying surplus food from digital platforms, food providers are also reticent to be associated with the stigma of leftovers commercialization. These results are consistent with those related to previous studies. Transactions involving food surpluses, non -standard or close to the expiration date, are configured as a significant challenge by the specific literature regarding food circularity strategies and new platform -users adoption (Morone et al., 2018) . Mulick et al. (2021) signaled that in the case of perishables close to the expirati on date, consumers are more inclined to associate them with lower food quality and higher safety risks. The selling of products close to the expiration date or with non -standard features aggravates potential users' perception of insecurity. In this sense, the founders of the Brazilian food -sharing platform seem to have found a solution. They signaled how relevant it is to conjoin with high reputation actors to overcome this barrier. Harvey et al. (2020) commented that food sharing practices occur preferably between parties who know each other in a family context (e.g., between family members, friends, and neighbors). Hence, to some extent, an essential activity in structuring business models is to prospect recognized commercial partners. In doing so, the pa rties need to exchange information and establish trusting relationships. Thereby, we can affirm that FWRP cannot be seen solely as a connection device between unknown parties. Their role expands to building valuable networks, nurturing their reputation and promoting win -win strategies. Apostolidis et al. (2021) and Mattila et al. (2020) argue that value co -creation occurs when different actors align their respective goals.

Our results outline that the Brazilian FWRP face significant organizational barriers and challenges in structuring their business models to couple economic, environmental, and social goals. We noticed that these challenges unleashed meaningful business models adjustments such as adapting value propositions, establishing new partnerships, a nd (re)structuring new value networks. Specifically, in the Brazilian case, meeting the social perspective means providing real contributions to reducing food insecurity, according to the innovators. Th eir discourses reminded that the country has millions of people living under food insecurity. For Bocken et al. (2014), traditional business models have already failed to deliver more sustainable solutions, being necessary to expand their value propositions towards environmental and social benefits. The liter ature also points out that tensions are likely to emerge when combining the three dimensions (economic, environmental and social) (Laasch, 201 8, Spieth et al., 2018) . On the other hand, Mazzuchelli et al. (2021) affirm that food sharing platforms count on reputation derived from reconciling economic, social, and environmental objectives to engage commercial partners and consumers, reinforcing this point of view.

According to the interviews, technology exerts a fundamental role in the success of FWRP s. For i nstance, apps can spur communication between disconnected parties, which is critical for perishable food (Michellini et al., 2018; Mulick et al., 2021). These authors claim that technology must reduce information asymmetries between the parties since consu mers do not see the product in physical stores but through out digital devices. Technology must promote interactivity between actors to boost consumer proximity with the platform (Mazzuchelli et al, 2021). Interviewees believe that developing user -friendly applications enhances familiarity, interaction, and information exchange in line with the literature. (eg. Mu et al., 2019). Technology exerts specific roles for platforms C and D, whose business models are based on business -to-business (B2B) transaction s. In the case of platform C, technology allows to monitor and structure the donation process throughout the food waste measurements and indicators. For platform D, the technology enables linking “disconnected” parties, playing the role called by Ciuli et a l (2020) as “circularity brokers”. These agents bind disconnected actors in terms of information and knowledge, one of the most significant circularity barriers described by circular economy literature (Kircherr et al., 2018; Vermunt et al., 2019).

In addi tion, the interviewees stated how they struggle to monetize their businesses due to the perception that food waste is part of the current business models in the food system and is considered inevitable for most. This finding is consistent with those of oth er studies (e.g. Ciuli et al., 2020), which also indicates that new actors' insertion imposes the challenge of finding

adequate remuneration strategies when margins are tight. The entrepreneurs surpassed this barrier by showing their commercial partners th at creating economic opportunities makes food recovery possible.

The responses also indicated that a lack of an institutional environment that nurtures sustainable and circular business models inhibits the emergence of food sharing practices such as FWRP. This scenario hinders the emergence of innovative solutions and contributes to the low economic viability of existent initiatives. As indicated by the literature (Ciuli et al., 2020), the interviewees also complained about the absence of tax incentives, m aking sharing activities more expensive than discarding activities. Respondents understand that the lack of a national policy to reduce food loss and waste constitutes the main institutional barrier faced by Brazilian innovators. This result is in line wit h De Jesus and Mendonça (2018) and García -Quevedo (2020) that pointed out institutional barriers critical for implementing circular initiatives. In short, innovators' leading solutions focus on minimizing the lack of an institutional environment to foster sustainable and circular business models to fight food waste in the Brazilian landscape. They try to meet sustainability requirements embodying economic, environmental, and social perspectives based on changing or readapting their business models.
5 CONC LUSIONS AND LIMITATIONS OF THE STUDY

Our results contribute to a better understanding of the barriers to implementing FWRP, specifically, in a developing country, such as Brazil, with few studies on these solutions to tackle food waste. From interviews wi th the founders of the platforms, we gathered several points of attention regarding the implementation of these innovations.

Based on the interviews, this work identified ten main barriers that affect the development and implementation of these platforms. Depicting these barriers, we encountered that many go beyond the technological perspective, confirming that these platforms cannot be seen only as mere digital marketplaces, but above all, as “connecting agents” in the food system that aim to recover non -commercial food. Technology plays an important role, but other factors constitute critical barriers to implementing these solutions as well. In the Brazilian context, the low engagement of actors (consumers and commercial partners) concerning food waste is an issue summed up by the lack of knowledge about these platforms. In this context, entrepreneurs see
as leading strategies: relational effort such as prospecting for reputational partners and creating communication strategies that bring actors closer to food waste cause.

In the view of the innovators, it is necessary to reconcile economic and environmental benefits with the proposition of relevant social benefits for the Brazilian context. Innovators see their initiatives as businesses that must generate relevant social impacts. For them, there is a strong relationship between reducing waste and helping to minimize food insecurity in the Brazilian case. Therefore, reconciling multiple benefits requires adapting business models and incorporating resources a nd activities that enable the delivery of these value propositions. Another relevant result representing the specific Brazilian context is the lack of an institutional environment that favors the emergence of sustainable and circular solutions in the fight against food waste. For those interviewed, food waste is part of the current food system's business models, which explains the difficulty of convincing commercial partners to perceive potential economic opportunities in waste -reducing strategies.

The barr iers encountered in our study are in line with those identified in previous works based on the literature about digital platforms in other countries. However, it is clear in our findings that the emergence and success of these initiatives in the Brazilian case are strictly dependent on the local reality. In the Brazilian scenario, it is reasonable to affirm that as far food waste is considered in the public and private agendas, more chances can be created to develop and support innovative solutions to tackl e food waste.

Finally, the results of this study cannot be generalized given the restricted number of platforms studied, conditioned by the reduced cases of existent initiatives in the country. Despite this, our study brings relevant insights into the fig ht against food waste in the Brazilian context. It draws attention to the importance of public policies and specific instruments such as tax incentives and legislation to encourage the emergence of different types of initiatives and solutions. One aspect n ot addressed by this study, but the authors recommend a further exploration, is a comprehension of Brazilian consumers' perspective (possible barriers, motivations, and expectations) about adopting food waste reducing platforms.
